content.question: How might this change affect the structure and function of the protein?

choices.label: The <math alttext="R group" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>R-group</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of the new amino acid, valine, has different chemical properties than the <math alttext="R group" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>R-group</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of cysteine. This will cause the protein to misfold and not function properly in the cell.

The new amino acid, valine, has replaced cysteine in the new protein. Since the number of amino acids has remained the same, there will be no change in the three-dimensional folding, or function, of the protein.
Since this is a linear section, it does not influence protein folding. Thus, there will be no change in protein structure or function.

Since the new amino acid is bounded on one side by an amino acid with a negatively charged <math alttext="R group" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>R-group</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and by an amino acid on the other side with a positively charged <math alttext="R group" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R-group</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the charges will balance and the protein will fold as usual.
